column2: a coastal town and civil parish on the Holderness Coast of the North Sea
column3: nicknamed the "Lobster Capital of Europe"
column4: belongs to the unitary authority and ceremonial county of the East Riding of Yorkshire. It is about 28 miles (45 km) north of Hull and 34 miles (55 km) east of York. The Gypsey Race enters the North Sea at its harbour. The 2011 Census gave a parish population of 35
column5: 369. As a minor sea-fishing port
column6: it is known for shellfish. Bridlington is the largest lobster port in the UK and Europe
column7: with over 300 tonnes of the crustaceans being landed there each year. Alongside small manufacturing
column9: its main trade is summer tourism. It is twinned with Millau
column12: Germany. It holds one of the UK's coastal weather stations. The Priory Church of St Mary and associated Bayle Gate are Grade I listed buildings on the site of an Augustinian Priory.

column1: Archaeological evidence shows habitation in the Bronze Age and in Roman Britain. The settlement after the Norman conquest was called Bretlinton
column2: later Berlington
column3: Brellington and Britlington
column4: before gaining its present name in the 19th century. The 1086 Domesday Book has Bretlinton. The several suggested origins all trace the name to the Anglo-Saxon custom of matching a personal name with a settlement type. Here the personal names advanced include Bretel
column5: Bridla and Berhtel
column6: attached to -ingtūn
column7: a Saxon term for a farm.The date of earliest habitation at Bridlington is unknown
column8: but the 2.5-mile  (4 km) man-made Danes Dyke at nearby Flamborough Head goes back to the Bronze Age. Some believe Bridlington was the site of a Roman station.

column2: now Woldgate
column3: can be traced across the Yorkshire Wolds into the town. Roman coins have been found: two hoards in the harbour area
column4: along with two Greek coins from the 2nd century BC — suggesting the port was in use long before the Roman conquest of Britain.It has been suggested that a Roman maritime station
column5: Gabrantovicorum
column6: stood near the modern town. In the early 2nd-century
column7: Ptolemy described what was probably Bridlington Bay in his Geography as Γαβραντουικων Ευλίμενος κόλπος "Gabrantwikone bay suitable for a harbour". No sheltered ancient harbour has been found
column8: but coastal erosion will have destroyed traces of any Roman installation near the harbour.

column2: Count Theodosius set up signal stations on the North Yorkshire coast to warn of Saxon raids. Flamborough Head is also believed to have had one – probably on Beacon Hill
column3: now a gravel quarry
column4: from where Filey
column5: Scarborough Castle and the Whitby promontory can be seen. A fort at Bridlington would have made a centre of operations for these. Another suggestion has been a line of signal stations stretching south round Bridlington Bay. This counterpart to the northern chain would have guarded a huge accessible anchorage from barbarian piracy.Near Dukes Park are two bowl barrows known as Butt Hills
column6: now designated ancient monuments in the National Heritage List for England of Historic England. Nearby are remains of an Anglo-Saxon cemetery on a farm outside Sewerby.In the Second World War
column7: Bridlington suffered several air raids that caused deaths and much bomb damage. The Royal Air Force had training schools in the town collectively known as RAF Bridlington

column2: with the earliest known reference to Bridlington
column3: records that Bretlinton headed the Hunthow Hundred held by Earl Morcar
column4: which passed to William the Conqueror by forfeiture. It also records the effect of the Harrying of the North: the annual value of the land had fallen from £32 in the time of Edward the Confessor to eight shillings (£0.40) at the time of the survey
column5: comprising two villeins and one socman with one and a half Carucate
column6: the rest being waste.The land was given to Gilbert de Gant
column8: in 1072. It was inherited by his son Walter and thereafter appears to follow the normal descent of that family. After the Dissolution of the Monasteries
column9: the manor remained with the Crown until 1624
column10: when Charles I passed it to Sir John Ramsey
column11: who had recently been created Earl of Holderness. In 1633
column12: Sir George Ramsey sold the manor to 13 inhabitants of the town
column13: on behalf of all the manor tenants. In May 1636
column14: a deed was drawn up empowering the 13 men as Lords Feoffees or trust holders of the Manor of Bridlington.

column1: Walter de Gant founded an Augustinian priory on the land in 1133
column2: confirmed by Henry I in a charter. Several succeeding kings confirmed and extended Walter de Gant's gift: King Stephen granted an additional right to have a port
column3: King John in 1200 gave permission for a weekly market and an annual fair
column4: and Henry VI allowed three annual fairs
column5: on the Nativity of Mary and the Deposition and Translation of St John of Bridlington in 1446. In 1415 Henry V visited the Priory to give thanks for victory at the Battle of Agincourt.The town began to grow in importance and size around the site of the dispersed priory. In 1643 Queen Henrietta Maria of France landed there with troops to support the Royalist cause in the English Civil War
column6: before moving on to York

column1: The town was originally two settlements: the Old Town about one mile (1.6 km) inland and the Quay area where the modern harbour lies. In 1837
column2: an Act of Parliament enabled the wooden piers to be replaced with two stone piers to the north and south. Apart from landing fish
column3: the port was used to transport corn: the 1826 Corn Exchange can still be seen in Market Place. There used to be mills in the town for grinding it
column4: which led in turn to some breweries starting locally
column5: but like most industry
column6: these had petered out by the latter part of the 20th century.

column1: Bridlington is within the unitary authority of the East Riding of Yorkshire. Its three wards are Bridlington North
column2: Bridlington South and Bridlington Old Town and Central
column3: returning eight councillors out of 67. The civil parish consists of the town of Bridlington and the villages of Bessingby and Sewerby. It is run by a town council of twelve councillors
column4: of which the three wards each return four.

column1: The Town Council coat of arms is described as: Per Sable and Argent three Gothic Capital letters B counterchanged on a Chief embattled of the second two Barrulets wavy Azure and for the Crest Issuant from a Coronet composed of eight Roses set upon a rim of a Sun rising Gules. with the motto:Signum Salutis Semper  meaning Always the bringer of good health.Bridlington lies in the large East Yorkshire parliamentary constituency that covers the mostly rural
column2: northern part of the county
column3: including the towns of Driffield
column4: Market Weighton and Pocklington. Its size and shape correspond to the East Yorkshire/North Wolds District under the earlier county of Humberside.

column1: The town has been subject to several changes in parliamentary representation. From 1290 to 1831 it was part of the large Yorkshire constituency
column2: sending two members until 1826
column3: when it gaied an additional two. Thereafter it was part of the East Riding of Yorkshire constituency until 1885
column4: returning two members. Further reform reduced the boundaries again
column5: to a single-member Buckrose seat until 1950. From 1950 to 1997
column6: Bridlington had its own MP
column7: until reform extended the boundary to include more countryside
column8: as the single-seat East Yorkshire constituency.

column1: Bridlington was designated a municipal borough in 1899. Local government reorganisation in 1974 included it in the new county of Humberside
column2: which caused resentment among residents against being excluded from Yorkshire. The town became the administrative centre of a local government district
column3: initially called the Borough of North Wolds but later changed to the Borough of East Yorkshire. The district disappeared when the county of Humberside was abolished in the 1990s
column4: the new East Riding of Yorkshire unitary authority absorbing it and the neighbouring county districts
column5: and Bridlington no longer having any formal local-government administrative status above town-council level.

column1: Bridlington lies 19 miles (31 km) north-north-east of Beverley
column2: 16 miles (26 km) south-east of Scarborough
column3: 11 miles (18 km) north-east of Driffield and 24 miles (39 km) north of Kingston upon Hull
column4: the principal city in the county. It is 179 miles (288 km) north of London. The height above sea level ranges from the beaches to 167 feet (51 m) on Bempton Lane on the outskirts. The Gypsey Race river flows through the town
column5: the last 1⁄2 mi (800 m) being below ground from the Quay Road Car Park. The solid geology of the area is mainly from the Cretaceous period
column6: consisting of Chalk overlain by Quaternary Boulder clay. The chalk is exposed as the land rises to the north of the town
column8: probably formed in the last interglacial
column9: extends inland at right angles to the present sea cliff
column10: and forms the promontory of Flamborough Head.Bridlington is in an area said to have the highest coastal erosion rate in Europe. Southwards the coast becomes low
column11: but northwards it is steep and very fine
column12: where the great spur of Flamborough Head projects eastwards. The sea front is guarded by a sea wall and a wide beach with wooden groynes to trap the sand. Offshore
column13: the Smithic Sands sandbank stretches out into the bay
column14: as an important habitat for many marine species. Bridlington north and south beaches have won EU environmental quality awards over the years.The Hull to Scarborough railway line divides the town from south-west to north-east and marks where the Old Town begins to its north. The Old Town has retail firms and industrial estates along with large residential areas. To the south the tourist attractions are accompanied by holiday accommodation and residential areas. The town's growth has enveloped the village of Hilderthorpe.

column1: The climate is temperate with warm summers and cool
column2: wet winters. The hottest months are from June to September
column3: with temperatures reaching an average high of 19 °C (66 °F) and falling to 12 °C (54 °F) at night. The average daytime temperatures in winter are 7 °C (45 °F) in the day and 2 °C (36 °F) at night.

column1: From the early history of Bridlington
column2: a small fishing port grew up near the coast
column3: later known as Bridlington Quay. After the discovery of a chalybeate spring
column4: the Quay developed in the 19th century into a seaside resort. Bridlington's first hotel was opened in 1805 and it soon became a popular resort with industrial workers from the West Riding of Yorkshire. A new railway station opened on 6 October 1846 between the Quay and the historic town. The area round it was developed and the two areas of the town were combined.

column1: Bridlington's popularity declined along with the industrial parts of the north and the rising popularity of cheap foreign holidays. Although the fishing fleet also declined
column2: the port remains popular with sea anglers for trips along the coast or further out to local shipwrecks. Bridlington has lucrative shellfish exports to France
column3: Spain and Italy
column4: said to be worth several million pounds a year.

column1: Bridlington is served by the Bridlington Free Press and the East Riding Mail. BBC Radio Humberside and Viking FM are radio stations which broadcast to the town
column2: and to the Hull and East Riding region. Greatest Hits Radio Yorkshire Coast also broadcasts to the town and up the coast as far north as Whitby.

column1: Jake Thackray's song "The Hair of the Widow of Bridlington" mocks Bridlington for the small-mindedness of its inhabitants.
The town is twinned with Millau in France and Bad Salzuflen in Germany
column2: under a triple twinning arrangement reached in 1991. Visits in each direction occur in alternate years.There are three main parks. Queen's Park is a small open area at the junction of the B1254 and Queensgate. Westgate Park is a mostly wooded area between Westgate and the A165 on the outskirts of the town. The largest open area is Duke's Park
column3: between Queensgate and the railway line. It hosts Bridlington Sports and Community Club
column4: a skate park and Bridlington Town Football Club. In addition
column5: there is a Sports Centre on the outskirts
column6: in Gypsey Road
column8: a gymnasium and squash courts. In January 2014
column9: Bridlington Leisure World on the Promenade
column12: closed for redevelopment. A temporary Olympic legacy pool was opened by Jo Jackson in January 2014 at the Bridlington Sports Centre in Gypsey Road
column13: while Leisure World was rebuilt. The new centre opened on 23 May 2016
column14: with an official opening on 1 July 2016 by Rebecca Adlington
column15: Gail Emms and Dean Windass.The town has a public library in King Street. Within the triangle of Station Avenue
column16: Station Road and Quay Road are the Town Hall
column17: Magistrates Court and several other government buildings. On South Marine Drive there is an RNLI Life Boat Station. There has been a life boat since 1805
column18: manned wholly by volunteers. It received a new Shannon-class lifeboat in 2018
column19: with some redevelopment to accommodate it.Close to the A165/A614 junction is Bridlington Hospital and the Ambulance Station. On the opposite side
column23: with a mix of full-time and on-call crew. There is a post office and depot not far from the level crossing in Quay Road.

column4: before a visit from Prince Charles and HRH Duchess of Cornwall as part of the special "Priory 900" celebrations.On 17 August 2013

column2: also known as the Priory Church of St Mary
column3: is a Grade I listed building
column4: named after the Augustinian Priory on which it was built. It was once fortified and the Bayle Gate nearby is what remains of that fortification and is also a Grade I listed building. It has a good-sounding ring of eight bells (tenor c. 24 cwt
column5: 05 t) with a long draft. It also has a large four-manual organ that boasts the widest "scaled" 32-foot reed (contra tuba) in the United Kingdom. Bridlington's war memorial is located in a small triangular garden at the junction of Prospect Street and Wellington Road. It was officially unveiled on Sunday 10 July 1921 by Captain S. H. Radcliffe

column3: where many well-known entertainers appeared

column5: to meet the demands of the 21st century. It has since begun to attract well-known names again: in 2013 indie rock bands the Kaiser Chiefs and Kasabian

column1: Bridlington is served by a railway station on the Yorkshire Coast Line between Hull and Scarborough. It opened on 6 October 1846 between the Quay and the Old Town.East Yorkshire Motor Services has a depot
column2: running nine local and six out-of-town bus routes
column3: including York
column4: Scarborough
column5: Driffield
column6: Beverley and Hull. Yorkshire Coastliner runs a service to Filey

column1: The town lies at the junction of two trunk roads: the A165 between Hull and Scarborough and the A614 between Bridlington and Nottingham. The A614 was extended in 1996 to include the length previously known as the A166 to York.
Four land trains run in Bridlington: the Yorkshire Rose
column2: Yorkshire Lass and Yorkshire Lad and the Spalight Express. Two run on the North Promenade between Leisure World and Sewerby Hall and Gardens linking Bridlington town centre with the summer car parks. One runs on the South Promenade linking Bridlington town centre to the park and ride and South Cliff Caravan Park. In the 1970s and 1980s there were two other trains — the Burlington Bertie and Bridlington Belle.

column1: Bridlington Civil Parish has seven primary schools
column2: counting Burlington Infant and Junior together. All are mixed gender
column3: for pupils between three or four and eleven years of age.

column1: Bay Primary School in St Alban Road had 335 pupils in 2013. Burlington Infant School in Marton Road had 239. Burlington Junior School
column2: also in Marton Road
column3: had 320 pupils. Hilderthorpe Primary School in Shaftesbury Road had 328 pupils. Martongate Primary School in Martongate had 424 pupils. Quay Academy in Oxford Street had 390 pupils. Our Lady and Saint Peter RC Primary School
column4: built in 1977 (formerly St Mary's R.C. Primary School) is located in George Street and had 210 pupils. New Pasture Lane Primary School in Burstall Hill had 177 pupils.

column1: Bridlington School is a mixed-gender specialist Sports and Design and Technology College for 11–18-year-olds. Located in Bessingby Road on the outskirts of the town
column2: it had a 2013 capacity of 1
column3: 244 pupils. There have been many notable past pupils. Headlands School in Sewerby Road caters for mixed-gender 11–18-year olds. It partners the town's other secondary school and had a 2013 capacity of 1
column4: 485 pupils.

column1: East Riding College provides tertiary education for students from 16. Located in St Mary's Walk
column2: it is close to Bay Primary School. Courses cover both academic and vocational subjects.

column1: All six GP practices closed their lists to new patients in 2016 due to problems with premises and staff shortages. The town has an elderly population
column2: which adds to demand. In May 2018 they were obliged by NHS England to reopen their lists
column3: but there was no funding for a proposed Health and Wellbeing Centre
column4: which was to have housed five surgeries.

column1: The main Anglican place of worship is the Priory Church of St Mary in Church Green. Christ Church in Quay Road
column2: next to the war memorial
column3: was built in 1841 by Gilbert Scott. Originally a chapel of ease
column4: it became a parish church in 1871 and is now a Grade II listed building. Emmanuel Church in Cardigan Road is a modern red-brick building
column5: also part of the Church of England.

column1: The Harbourside Evangelical Church stands in a side road off Bridge Street. The Kingdom Hall of the Jehovah's Witnesses is in Station Avenue. The Cornerstone Church
column2: once known as The Chapel Hall
column3: is an Evangelical Church in St John's Walk. There has been a Baptist church in the town since 1698
column4: the current place of worship being on the corner of Quay Road and Portland Place. On the corner of St John Street and Brett Street is the Free Presbyterian Church. The independent Evangelical Church in Ferndale Terrace is called Calvary Chapel by the Sea.The strong Methodist Church presence in the town since 1770 is covered in various locations. St John's Burlington Methodist Church in St John's Street remains. The chapel in the Promenade lasted from 1852 until 1957 as part of the United Methodist Free Church. The Primitive Methodists established a chapel in St John Street in 1833
column5: but moved to a nearby location in 1849. This in turn was rebuilt in 1877 and lasted until 1970. The Primitive Methodists also had a chapel known as the Central Methodist Church on the Quay in 1833. It moved to Chapel Street in 1870 and built itself larger premises there in 1878. In 1969 it joined with the Chapel Street Methodist Church
column6: which was in existence in 1810 in what was originally Back Street. This was rebuilt in 1873 and lasted until 1999
column7: when it became the final Methodist congregation to unite with the present church.The Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady and St Peter stands in Victoria Road. The Catholics had long lacked a permanent mission in the town. A previous 1886 building in Wellington Road had not provided sufficient space when a mission was eventually granted. Modern premises were built in 1893–1894 by Arthur Lowther. The church hall adjacent was added in 1963. The connection to the sea is evident on the dedication to Our Lady
column8: also known as the Star of the Sea
column10: Patron Saint of Fishermen. The convent in the High Street is associated with the church and though now run by the Sisters of Mercy

column1: The town has a semi-professional Bridlington Town A.F.C.
column2: founded in 1918
column3: refounded in 1994
column4: and now playing in the Northern Counties East League Premier Division (NCEL). Its home ground is a stadium in Queensgate. The team's honours include the FA Vase in 1993
column5: three NCEL Premier Division titles and 15 East Riding County FA Cups. The town also has a junior football club
column6: Bridlington Rangers
column7: with teams playing in various age groups of the Hull Boys Sunday Football League. Bridlington Sports Club plays in the Humber Premier League.

column2: the top team of Bridlington Cricket Club plays in the York and District Senior League Division 1. It also runs three Saturday league teams and junior teams.Bridlington Rugby Union Football Club plays next to Bridlington Town A.F.C. at Dukes Park. It fields two senior men's teams
column3: a women's team and numerous junior sections. The Men's 1st XI played in Yorkshire 1 for the 2019 season
column4: after spending three years in North east 1. It also reached the final of the RFU National Intermediate Cup at Twickenham on 4 May 2013
column5: where it lost 22–30 to Brighton Blues.Bridlington Hockey Club has existed for over a century. It currently plays home matches at Bridlington Astro Centre in Bessingby Road. It also fields two ladies' sides and a junior development section for girls and boys. An annual hockey festival is held
column6: with both men's and women's tournaments. A new format added to the festival for 2014 gave chances for men and women to play together.Other sports played around Bridlington include tennis and pétanque.
